title: Pandas: loc vs iloc
story: loc uses labels, iloc uses integer positions. Understanding the difference prevents common indexing errors.
instructions: Use iloc to select the 2nd row (index 1) and print only the 'name' and 'score' values as a Series.
starterCode:
import pandas as pd

data = {
    'name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],
    'score': [85, 92, 78],
    'grade': ['B', 'A', 'C']
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Select 2nd row (position 1) with iloc
result = df.iloc[1][['name', 'score']]
print(result)
solutionHidden:
import pandas as pd

data = {
    'name': ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'],
    'score': [85, 92, 78],
    'grade': ['B', 'A', 'C']
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)
result = df.iloc[1][['name', 'score']]
print(result)

tests.description: Should print name and score for Bob
tests.expected:
name      Bob
score      92
Name: 1, dtype: object

hints.text: iloc uses integer positions: df.iloc[1] gets the 2nd row (0-indexed).
Use df.iloc[row_position][column_list] to select specific columns from a row.
